'''Alice Wong''' (born 1974) is a [[disability rights]] activist based in San Francisco, CA.
==Career== Alice Wong is the founder and Project Coordinator of the Disability Visibility Project,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nbcnews.com/news/asian-america/alice-wong-sets-out-chronicle-disability-history-n184961|title=Alice Wong Sets Out to Chronicle Disability History - NBC News|publisher=|accessdate=3 November 2016}}</ref> a project collecting oral histories of people with disabilities in the United States that is being run in coordination with [[StoryCorps]]. The Disability Visibility Project was created on the 25th anniversary of the [[Americans with Disabilities Act of 1990]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://talkpoverty.org/2015/07/30/telling-stories-people-with-disabilities/|title=Telling Our Stories: Why I Launched the Disability Visibility Project|date=30 July 2015|publisher=|accessdate=3 November 2016}}</ref>
Wong also serves as an advisory board member for APIDC, Asians and Pacific Islanders with Disabilities of California. She is also a Presidential appointee to the [[National Council on Disability]] an independent federal agency which advises the President, Congress, and other federal agencies on disability policies, programs, and practices.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.ucsf.edu/news/2013/01/13465/president-obama-appoints-alice-wong-national-council-disability|title=President Obama Appoints Alice Wong to National Council on Disability|publisher=|accessdate=3 November 2016}}</ref>
In 2015, Wong attended the reception at the White House for the 25th anniversary of the [[Americans with Disabilities Act of 1990|Americans With Disabilities Act]] via telepresence robot. She was the first person to visit the White House and the President by robot presence.<ref>" San Francisco’s Alice Wong’s historical White House visit". SFGate, July 22, 2015. http://blog.sfgate.com/lshumaker/2015/07/22/san-franciscos-alice-wongs-historical-white-house-visit/</ref>
Wong has [[spinal muscular atrophy]], a neuromuscular disorder.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.ucsf.edu/news/2016/03/402181/alice-wong-wins-national-disabilities-organization-award| title=Alice Wong Wins National Disabilities Organization Award| author=Mitzi Baker| publisher=[[University of California San Francisco]]| date=2016-03-22| accessdate=2017-02-28}}</ref>
==Awards== For her leadership on behalf of the disability community, Wong received the Mayor’s Disability Council Beacon Award in 2010, the first-ever Chancellor’s Disability Service Award in 2010, and the 2007 Martin Luther King, Jr. Award at UCSF.

{{Infobox person | name = Arnold Frutkin | birth_name = Arnold W. Frutkin | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1918|11|30}} | birth_place = [[New York City, New York]] | title = Deputy Director of the U.S. National Committee
Associate administrator for external relations | term = 1957-1979 }} '''Arnold Frutkin''' (born November 30, 1918){{cite book|title=Who's who in Government - Volume 3|year=1977|publisher=Marquis Who's Who, LLC|isbn=0837912032|page=206}} was the Deputy Director of the [[NASA]] international programs office between 1957 and 1978,{{cite web|url=https://history.nasa.gov/astp/bios.html#Frutkin|title=Arnold W. Frutkin (1918- )|publisher=[[NASA]]|accessdate=6 April 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100408003358/https://history.nasa.gov/astp/bios.html| archivedate= 8 April 2010 | deadurl= no}} and later, the associate administrator for external relations. He was the NASA Deputy Director for international affairs during the [[Space Race]] between the [[United States]] and the [[Soviet Union]].{{cite journal|last=Duff|first=Brian|date=December 1994 – January 1995|title=Tovarich! |journal=Air & Space/Smithsonian}} ==Biography== Frutkin first started working for NASA when he was hired as deputy director for the U.S. National Committee during the [[International Geophysical Year]], July 1, 1957, to December 31, 1958. This title later changed to assistant administrator for international affairs in 1963.{{cite web|url=http://www.astronautix.com/astros/frutkin.htm|title=Arnold W Frutkin: American Scientist|publisher=www.astronautix.com|accessdate=6 April 2010}} Frutkin was employed by NASA as deputy director of the international programs office during the [[space race]] between the [[United States]] and the [[Soviet Union]]. After retiring, Frutkin commented although he had always disliked the space race, he had nonetheless felt disappointed by the success of [[Sputnik 1]]. In 1970, Frutkin and [[Thomas O. Paine|Thomas Paine]] held discussions with the Soviets that would later become the base for the [[Apollo–Soyuz Test Project|ASTP]]. Frutkin wrote a letter{{When|date=February 2011}} asking the French space program to reaffirm their pledge not to launch commercial communications satellites under the [[Intelsat]] project's agreement that no other communications satellites besides Intelsat would be launched for commercial purposes. France had requested that NASA launch a French satellite which they identified as a research instrument. NASA gave the project the go ahead, but later, some French officials started to claim that the satellite would be used for commercial purposes and the launch of the satellite was cancelled. Lebeau, an employee of the French space program, claimed that Frutkin had refused to launch the French satellite, a comment that resulted in Frutkin barring him from his office. Frutkin took a copy of the letter he wrote with him when he went to meetings in Europe, so as he could produce it when he was queried as to why he supposedly refused the French project. Frutkin believed that the USA had never lost the [[Korean War]] as the aim of the USA had been to prevent North Korea from taking over South Korea, in which they had been successful. This opinion went against what many of his colleagues at the time, including Thomas Paine, believed. Nonetheless, in 1973, Frutkin was awarded the [[NASA Distinguished Service Medal]] by Thomas Paine, and Frutkin commented that Paine had always been "wonderful" to him.{{cite web|url=http://www.jsc.nasa.gov/history/oral_histories/NASA_HQ/Administrators/FrutkinAW/FrutkinAW_3-8-02.pdf|title=Oral history Transcript - Arnold W. Frutkin|publisher=www.jsc.nasa.gov|accessdate=6 April 2010}} In 1978 Frutkin was appointed as the associate administrator for external relations for NASA. He held this post until his retirement in 1979. ==References== {{reflist}} {{Portal bar|Spaceflight|United States}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Frutkin, Arnold}} [[Category:NASA people]] [[Category:1918 births]] [[Category:Living people]]

[[Youssou N'Dour]] | website = {{URL|www.aureliomusic.net}} }} '''Aurelio Martínez,''' professionally known as '''Aurelio,''' is a Honduran musician and politician. He is a singer, percussionist, and guitarist known for his [[Garifuna music]] and is considered a Cultural Ambassador of the [[Garifuna]] people.{{cite news|last1=Gould|first1=Jens Erik|title=Honduras: A Garifuna Legend Inspired to Revive HIV Prevention Battle|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/music/worldfolkandjazz/8652559/Aurelio-Martinez-Music-is-the-way-to-reach-people.html|accessdate=19 October 2015|work=[[Pulitzer Center on Crisis Reporting]]|date=21 March 2013}}http://www.aureliomusic.net/bio/https://realworldrecords.com/artist/3662/aurelio/ According to the Guardian, he became the leading Garifuna performer after the death of musician [[Andy Palacio]].https://www.theguardian.com/music/2017/jan/19/aurelio-darandi-review-real-world-stonetree-martinez-guayo-cedeno From 2006-2010, Martinez served as a congressman for the [[National Congress of Honduras]], becoming its first black member.{{cite news|last1=Eyre|first1=Banning|title=Aurelio: A Musical Guardian Of The Garifuna|url=https://www.npr.org/2011/02/15/133404775/aurelio-a-musical-guardian-of-the-garifuna|accessdate=19 October 2015|work=[[All Things Considered]]|publisher=[[NPR]]|date=15 February 2011}}{{cite news|last1=Diaz|first1=Ruben|title=Mr. Aurelio Martinez, Musical Legend and former member of the Honduran National Congress, speaks during the Reception Celebrating Garifuna-American Heritage Month|url=https://www.nysenate.gov/newsroom/articles/ruben-diaz/mr-aurelio-martinez-musical-legend-and-former-member-honduran-national|accessdate=19 October 2015|work=[[New York State Senate]]|date=18 March 2015}} == Biography == Singer-songwriter, guitarist and percussionist, Aurelio Martinez aka AURELIO (born 1969), is one of Central America’s most gifted performers. Born in Honduras, the artist is known for his powerful and evocative voice. He is a major tradition-bearer of the Garifuna culture and music and he is considered nowadays as the Cultural Ambassador of the Garifuna nation. The Garinagu, commonly known as the Garifuna are people of Amerindian and West African descents who live along the coasts of Belize, Guatemala, Honduras, and Nicaragua. The original home of the Garifuna is St. Vincent (one of the windward islands in the West Indies) from which they were deported in 1796 by the British government and landed on Roatan island, situated in the Bay Islands of Honduras. Aurelio grew up in a small Caribbean village called Plaplaya, surrounded by a family of talented musicians. His father was a well-known local troubadour who improvised Paranda songs containing Garifuna roots rhythms and Latin sounds. Following the influence of his uncles and grandfather, he became a brilliant drummer in his early childhood. From his vocally gifted mother, he learned to sing and picked up many songs she crafted. Actually, Aurelio began performing at Garifuna ceremonies when just a boy, even at the most sacred events where children were usually not even allowed. At the age of 14, the young man became a respected musician with a firm grounding in Garifuna rhythms, rituals and songs. While attending secondary school at the provincial capital of La Ceiba, Aurelio dove into diverse and innovative musical projects that took him outside the traditional sphere of performance. By this time, he played professionally with popular Latin ensembles and refined his musical skills. In the late 80’s, he created his first group called Lita Ariran, who was one of the first Garifuna traditional music and dance group to appear on the international scene and most specifically in Japan. His first album was produced by his friend Akira Tomita with the Japanese company JVC World Sounds (Grupo Garifuna de Honduras, LITA ARIRAN (JVC Records, 1995). Later, Aurelio received the award for the Best singer of Garifuna music and his group Lita Ariran was rewarded for the Best cultural group of the year at the Garifuna World Music Awards, in New York (1998). The less we could say is that Lita Ariran‘s first and unique album remains most certainly a legendary treasure of the Garifuna music nowadays. In 1997, Aurelio meets his Belizean friend and fellow musician Andy Palacio. The two artists struck up a decades-long friendship thanks in part to their shared hopes for the future of Garifuna music and culture. Through Palacio, Aurelio met Ivan Duran, the tireless producer behind Belize’s Stonetree Records. The same year, the young artist participated in a paranda project, including the King of Paranda Paul Nabor “Nabi”, Junie Aranda, Jursino Cayetano, Andy Palacio, among others. Critics around the world acknowledge PARANDA: AFRICA IN CENTRAL AMERICA (Stonetree Records, 1999) as being one of the best albums to come out of this part of the world. It is in fact a very rich collection of three generations of paranderos with a depth and range that grows with each listen. From the haunting, bluesy exuberance of Paul Nabor's "Naguya Nei" to the fresh sounds of Aurelio’s "Africa", this album takes the listener through the tapestry of feeling and soulful striving that lies at the heart of the Garifuna culture. In 2004, Aurelio releases his first solo album called GARIFUNA SOUL produced by his friend and long time collaborator Ivan Duran (Stonetree Records, 2004), backed by some of Belize’s and Honduras’ best studio musicians who improvised adeptly on Garifuna percussion, saxophone, electric and bass guitars. Undoubtedly, the artist takes the music into the future without compromising whatsoever the cultural foundations of his inspiration. Aurelio's rich resonant voice and soulful acoustic songs caught the attention of the global music press and saw him as a tradition-bearer with an innate musicality and subtle innovative streak. Indeed, AfroPop Worldwide names him “Newcomer of the year”. Two years later (2006), Aurelio, a new born gifted musician takes on another role as a politician in the Honduran National Congress, becoming this way the first Garifunacongressman of his region in the country’s history. For this occasion, the politician’s main goal was to represent and support the Garifuna people through concrete manifestations that would protect their integrity as a whole. Precisely, the idea was to lead innovative actions to improve the daily life of this population as well as to feed and preserve their cultural treasures. In the mean time, the Spanish public television (RTVE) produces: Honduras y Belice: la Aventura Garifuna, an original documentary that features simultaneously, the encounter between old paranda’s singers and the Garifuna’s way of life of yesterday and today’s generations. Aurelio is the star of this journey: a very popular young musician who later becomes known as one of the best paranderos. Thanks to its richness, this documentary is definitely an interesting audiovisual reference to introduce oneself into the surrounding world of the artist. In 2007, Aurelio was invited to participate in the album WATINA (Stonetree Records, Cumbancha, 2007) featuring Andy Palacio and The Garifuna Collective who received the prestigious WOMEX Award, a respected acknowledgment from the world music industry. Additionally, the album Watina was declared the Greatest World Music Album of All Times by Amazon.com in 2010. Andy Palacio passed away unexpectedly at the young age of 48, leaving the Garifuna community stunned and bereft. ”Aurelio was still a congressman, but he left the congress session to go to Belize for the funeral,” Duran recalls. “He hadn’t been playing guitar for months because of his intense political commitments. But after Andy’s passing, he gave a few concerts and he knew he needed to start recording right away.” Together with Ivan Duran, several veteran Garifuna musicians, and the occasional local ensemble dropping into the studio, Aurelio began laying down the tracks for this recording in a cabana on the beach. Laru Beya was not only a way of honoring Andy Palacio as a person; it was a means for continuing his mission of uplifting and expanding what it meant to be a Garifuna artist. By the year 2008, Aurelio was selected worldwide musician by the Afropop legend Youssou N’Dour, within the Rolex Mentor and Protégé Arts Initiative. Most definitely, this was a major event allowing Aurelio and the Garifuna music to open up for the first time to African famous musicians. With no doubt, this opportunity of sharing was another main step in the artist’s developing career. Aside of exchanging valuable points of view about the former it gave him new ideas about musical technical features as well as an exciting possibility to share the stage with Youssou N’ Dour in places such as Senegal, New York (Nokia Theater) and Vienna (Vienna Jazz Festival). At the end of this journey, Aurelio’s dream of traveling one day to the African continent finally became true. Three years later, as part of a result of Youssou N’Dour’s collaboration, Aurelio releases his second album LARU BEYA (Stonetree Records, Real World Records, SUBPOP, 2011), a compilation of soulful songs linking back to the African roots. N’Dour adds his stirring vocals to two of its songs, while elsewhere there is backing from those great veterans of the Afro-Cuban scene, Orchestra Baobab, and from Senegalese rapper Sen Kumpé. Laru Beya wins sixth place in the Top 20 World Music Albums of 2011 in the WorldMusic.co.uk Award. “Aurelio is a highly talented musician, conscious composer and passionate performer with an excellent band behind him, as well as being the prime advocate for a unique culture. If anyone is going to put the Garifuna culture onto the map, it is Aurelio Martinez”, wrote the WorldMusic.co.uk website. After his debut in the African scene, Aurelio makes a return to his musical roots with his third album LANDINI, (Stonetree Records, Real World Records, 2014). This last composition draws a traditional scenario of the Garifuna community way of life. Most specifically, the album shows a gentle picture of the paranda musical environment in Plaplaya, the artist’s dear hometown. Traditionally, after a long day of fishing, villagers return into their boats to the river landing and gather for a convivial paranda session. This symbolic image leads us to the album’s present name: “landini”, from the English word: “landing”. According To Aurelio, "I consider this album to be the sound of my Garifuna people. On the previous album [Laru Beya] we experimented and collaborated with other artists to reconnect what was lost between Africa and America. This album is purely Garifuna, and the entire spirit of the music reflects the Garifuna experience. My mother is the sole inspiration for this album. She sees herself reflected in me, to a large degree, the only one of the family who could fulfill her dream of singing professionally. She's the best example I have in my life of what a human being should be, my main consultant and confidante." Lándini was named to multiple 2014 year-end critics lists, including: #3 on The Sunday Times Ten Best World Music Albums of 2014, #3 on fRoots Critic's Poll New Albums of 2014, #2 World Music Central Best World Music Albums 2014, Songlines 10 Best Albums of the Year 2014, Curious Animal's Best Albums of 2014, #1 Songlines 50 Greatest World Music Albums of the Last Years. The Garifuna community of New York honored Aurelio in March 2015 with a special musical tribute and concert to celebrate the 30th anniversary of his career. In January 17, Aurelio launched his new album DARANDI, a collection of Aurelio’s favorite songs from his career recorded to capture the sound of his incendiary live performances accompanied by some of the Garifuna world’s brightest musical talents. The album has been receiving great reviews by the press: “The Garifuna have a history of escaping slavery … That experience informs the indomitable spirit and characteristic joie de vivre of their music, expressed via the paranda, a unique up-tempo rhythm and melodies that are as listenable as they are danceable to. ***** ” (Morning Star). “This is his best album to date … Recording with his band 'as live' in the studio, he brings new energy and emotion to favorites that range from the charming and slinky 'Laru Beya' to the lament 'Yange,' or a fresh version of 'Dondo,' a paranda classic driven on by tremolo electric guitar lines from Guayo Cedeño. **** ” (The Guardian). fRoots named Aurelio as “the finest living exponent of the music of the Garifuna people” and London Evening Standard called him “one of the great artists of Latin America." “We’re not going to let this culture die. I know I must continue my ancestors’ legacy and find new ways to express it. Few people know about it, but I adore it, and it’s something I must share with the world.” Aurelio. == Discography == === Solo records === * 2017: ''Darandi'' (Real World Records / Stonetree Records) https://realworldrecords.com/release/661/darandi/ https://aureliomusic.bandcamp.com/album/darandihttps://open.spotify.com/album/3kjiDvqvRhZIgrz3GnQVER * 2014: ''Lándini'' ([[Real World Records]] / Stonetree Records){{cite web|title=Lándini - Aurelio, 2014|url=https://realworldrecords.com/release/635/landini/|website=[[Real World Records]]|accessdate=19 October 2015}} * 2011: ''Laru Beya'' ([[Real World Records]] / Stonetree Records){{cite web|title=Laru Beya - Aurelio, 2011|url=https://realworldrecords.com/release/573/laru-beya/|website=[[Real World Records]]|accessdate=19 October 2015}} * 2004: ''Garifuna Soul'' (Stonetree Records){{cite web|title= Garifuna Soul - Aurelio Martinez|url=http://www.stonetreerecords.com/albums/garifuna_soul.php|website=Stonetree Records|accessdate=19 October 2015}} * 1995: ''Songs of the Garifuna: Lita Ariran'' (JVC World Sounds) === Collaborations === * 2007: ''Wátina'' - Andy Palacio & The Garifuna Collective (Stonetree Records / Cumbancha){{cite web|title=Andy Palacio & the Garifuna Collective, Watina|url=http://stonetreerecords.com/albums/watina.php|website=Stonetree Records|accessdate=19 October 2015}} * 1999: ''Paranda'' - Various Artists (Stonetree Records ){{cite web|title=Paranda - Various Artists|url=http://www.stonetreerecords.com/albums/paranda.php|website=Stonetree Records|accessdate=19 October 2015}} == References == {{Reflist|30em}} == External links == * {{official|http://www.aureliomusic.net}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Martinez, Aurelio}} [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Deputies of the National Congress of Honduras]] [[Category:Honduran male singers]] [[Category:Honduran musicians]] [[Category:Honduran people of African descent]] [[Category:Garifuna people]] [[Category:Garifuna music]]

(Pre-series) | title = | spouse = [[Martha Logan]] (divorced) | children = | nationality = | lbl21 = Political party | data21 = [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican Party]] | lbl22 = Hometown | data22 = [[Santa Barbara, California]] | lbl23 = [[Alma mater]] | data23 = [[Princeton University]] ([[Bachelor of Arts]]) }} '''Charles Logan''' is a [[Character (arts)|fictional character]] played by [[Gregory Itzin]] in the television series ''[[24 (TV series)|24]]''. During the show's fourth season, Logan is the [[Vice President of the United States]] who is sworn into office as [[President of the United States]] when former President [[Minor characters in 24#24: Season 4|John Keeler]] is critically injured in a [[terrorist attack]]. Subsequently, Logan's administration fell into corruption. The show's fifth season sees him engage in a massive conspiracy to solidify United States oil interests. Logan appears in the fifth and eighth seasons as the primary antagonist. For the role, Itzin received two [[Primetime Emmy Award]] nominations for [[Primetime Emmy Award for Outstanding Supporting Actor in a Drama Series|Outstanding Supporting Actor in a Drama Series]] in 2006 and [[Primetime Emmy Award for Outstanding Guest Actor in a Drama Series|Outstanding Guest Actor in a Drama Series]] in 2010. ==Characterization== Charles Logan has a [[Bachelor of Arts]] degree in [[History]] from [[Princeton University]].{{cite web|url=http://fox.com/24/profiles/season5/cl.htm |title=FOX Broadcasting Company: 24 |publisher=FOX 24 |accessdate=2008-07-08 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080419032711/http://www.fox.com/24/profiles/season5/cl.htm |archivedate=2008-04-19 |deadurl=yes |df= }} Prior to his vice-presidency, he served as the [[Chief Executive Officer|CEO]] of Western Energy Coal & Reserve; he also served in the California State Legislature, as [[Lieutenant Governor of California]] and as a [[United States Senate|United States Senator]]. Logan possesses several characteristics that diminish his capacity to serve as president. In contrast to Palmer, Logan is seemingly incapable of making hard decisions independently, relying on the recommendations of his advisors. If none are available, Logan tries to withdraw himself from the situation entirely. Additionally, his resolve is weak, as he rarely stands behind the decisions he makes. Furthermore, he boasts of his achievements after a crisis is over, even if his claims do not reflect the reality of the situation. After [[24 (season 5)|Day 5]] revealed that Logan was behind the backfiring conspiracy, show executive producer Evan Katz said that the President was more of a man hiding a secret and was just being a little smarter about how he projects himself. Star [[Kiefer Sutherland]] also noted that people like Logan who are underestimated can become very dangerous because it gives them a sort of cover.{{cite web|last=Levin |first=Gary |url=https://www.usatoday.com/life/television/news/2006-04-09-24-prez_x.htm |title='24' prez pivots from weasel to evil |publisher=Usatoday.com |date=2006-04-09 |accessdate=2010-09-27}} In the commentary for the show's fifth season DVD, Itzin mentions how he, with the help of [[Jean Smart]], who played his wife Martha, developed an extensive backstory for Logan to help focus his performance. Among other things, he decided that Logan was the son of a distinguished military and political leader. Logan's father physically abused him as a child, which Logan references twice in the finale; first when he tells Jack that he's a lot tougher than he appears to be, then again when he warns Martha that she doesn't know what pain is. The backstory also included the Logans' son, who died in his twenties several years ago (which might have been the cause of Martha's mental breakdown). Throughout the day, Logan carried a small chain in his pocket which had been a gift from his son, though most shots that show the chain (such as when his pockets are emptied when Jack interrogates him) were cut for time. Itzin also commented that [[David Palmer (24 character)|David Palmer]] was also a friend to Logan's son and visited him extensively. Logan's reappearance in the sixth season show a man who is deeply sorry about his actions in the previous season. Logan has all but stated he is now a [[Born again Christianity|born again]] [[Christian]] and is searching for redemption. A scene of Logan in private confirms this, showing him grasping a [[Bible]] and quoting a passage for comfort. While he showed no ulterior motives, both President [[Wayne Palmer]] and Logan's ex-wife [[Martha Logan|Martha]] understandably showed doubt as to whether Logan has truly changed. Itzin has acknowledged a physical resemblance between himself and President [[Richard Nixon]]: "I have the hairline, and my posture’s mediocre."[https://www.nytimes.com/2006/08/27/arts/television/27itzk.html President Logan Puts a Spin on the Plots of ‘24’] ==Appearances== {{plot|date=October 2008}} ===24: Season 4=== Logan is first contacted by President [[List of minor characters in 24#24: Season 4|Keeler]] when it is discovered that [[Minor characters in 24#Mitch Anderson|Mitch Anderson]] commandeered a [[stealth fighter]] with the intent to shoot down [[Air Force One]]. Efforts to neutralize the stealth fighter fail, and Air Force One is shot down. As a result, the incapacitated Keeler was deemed unable to serve as president, and Logan was appointed president as a result of the [[25th Amendment]]. After being sworn in, Logan is informed by one of his senior advisors, [[Mike Novick]], that Marwan and his terrorist organization have managed to recover several codes to the nation's nuclear arsenal. While Marwan's people manage to steal a nuclear warhead and successfully launch it on board a missile, [[Counter Terrorist Unit|CTU]] [[Los Angeles]] desperately attempts to track him. Unfortunately, Logan proves unprepared for both the office and the crisis. When CTU arrests an American civilian named Joe Prado due to his employment under Marwan, Logan is hesitant to face the political risk of detaining Prado without charge. Logan is slow to act, even though CTU and Novick point out that Prado is their only means of finding Marwan in time. Unwilling to let Logan waste precious time, CTU agent Jack Bauer convinces his superiors to release Prado; afterwards he tortures Prado into revealing one of Marwan's hideouts. Logan, furious that Bauer has acted without his approval, dispatches the [[United States Secret Service|Secret Service]] to arrest him. However, the Secret Service disrupts Bauer's operation to capture Marwan, allowing him to escape. Logan begins to doubt his ability to govern during the crisis. In response, Novick recruits [[David Palmer (24 character)|David Palmer]] as an advisor, due to the crises he has faced as president. Though Logan initially welcomes Palmer's counsel, he becomes increasingly isolated as Palmer and Novick assume a more active role in leading the search for Marwan. Eventually, CTU locates Marwan. Although he kills himself to avoid capture, CTU manages to use Marwan's equipment to track the missile and shoot it down before it reaches its target. Despite his lack of leadership during the crisis, Logan quickly accepts credit for his presumed handling of the situation. His only concession to Palmer is a private statement that he had "played a role". In the midst of the hunt for Marwan, Palmer authorizes a covert CTU operation led by Bauer to extract Lee Jong, an associate of Marwan's, from the Chinese consulate in Los Angeles. During the incident, the Chinese Consul is killed by friendly fire. Chinese officials eventually link the operation to Bauer and demand his extradition. [[Walt Cummings]], Logan's aide, suggests arranging Bauer's murder to prevent his knowledge from being exploited by the Chinese. Though Logan vocally rejects this proposal, Novick later overhears a phone conversation in which Cummings orders a Secret Service agent to kill Bauer before he is turned over to Chinese authorities. Palmer informs Logan of Cumming's actions, but the president disbelieves the story and refuses to take action. Palmer warns Bauer of the threat on his life, causing Bauer and his CTU colleagues to fake his death. While Bauer goes into hiding, Logan remains unaware of the truth, believing that the situation has been resolved. ===24: Season 5=== Logan prepares to meet [[President of Russia|Russian president]] [[Yuri Suvarov]] to sign an anti-terrorism defense [[treaty]], seeing the event as the highlight of his presidency. He is startled by the news of David Palmer's assassination, which takes place the morning the treaty is to be signed. [[First Lady]] [[Martha Logan]] insists that Palmer had previously contacted her, warning of a possible terrorist attack. Logan, while seemingly sympathetic, is skeptical given her history of [[mental illness]]. Meanwhile, Eastern European [[separatist]]s take hostages at an airport in opposition to the treaty. Logan orders CTU to organize a rescue, allowing the treaty to be signed as planned. [[Walt Cummings]] comes to Logan and admits his complicity in Palmer's murder and the airport incident, and further confesses his involvement in an imminent terrorist attack involving the dispersal of [[nerve gas]]. Cummings claims that the attack will justify a stronger U.S. presence in [[Asia]], and promote a greater acquisition of [[oil]] from the region. He also says that the American agent monitoring the attack has gone dark and is now beyond Cummings' reach. Logan is apparently appalled by Cummings' actions. Meanwhile, Bauer, who has emerged from hiding to investigate Palmer's assassination, discovers that Cummings knows more about the plot than what he let on to Logan. After convincing [[United States Secret Service|Secret Service]] agent [[Aaron Pierce (24 character)|Aaron Pierce]] to let him speak with Logan, Bauer confronts Cummings and forces him to confess. Logan promptly orders Cummings arrested. Unfortunately, when government forces move in on the location of the nerve gas, they find it missing and the American agent dead. The terrorists had apparently discovered Cummings' plan. Shortly after reinstating Bauer at CTU, Logan learns that Cummings has committed suicide. Meanwhile, the terrorists plan to release the nerve gas in a [[Los Angeles]] shopping mall. CTU head [[Lynn McGill]] urges Logan to allow the terrorists to succeed—potentially killing up to nine-hundred Americans—in the hopes of catching them and safeguarding the remaining canisters. Despite [[Audrey Raines]]' insistence that such a decision would be immoral, Logan agrees to McGill's plan. However, due to Bauer's last-minute intervention, the attack only kills eleven people. Immediately thereafter, separatist leader [[Vladimir Bierko]] gives an [[ultimatum]] to Logan, demanding President Suvarov's motorcade route or else face the release of the remaining nerve gas. Ultimately, Logan caves to their demands. Unbeknownst to Logan, Martha joins Suvarov's motorcade in a successful attempt to have the route changed. After CTU thwarts the planned attack, Logan's vice president, [[Hal Gardner]], suggests that he declare [[martial law]] until the end of the crisis. Logan does so, much to the dismay of Martha and Novick. It is revealed that Logan has collaborated with former CTU agent [[Christopher Henderson]] in orchestrating the day's attacks. When CTU finally defeats the terrorists, Logan turns his full attention to eliminating all evidence of his crimes, ordering Henderson to stop Bauer and [[Wayne Palmer]] from retrieving an audio tape incriminating him in David Palmer's assassination. Logan has Bauer framed for the murder and issues an executive warrant for his arrest. When questioned, Logan claims to have evidence which he will disclose after Bauer is in custody. Once Jack retrieves the tape, he heads to [[Van Nuys Airport]] to hand it off to [[Secretary of Defense]] [[James Heller]], with the intent to bring down Logan. Once Heller is in possession of the recording, he attempts to cut a deal with Logan, requesting he step down quietly, and in return the recording will never see the light of day. Logan prepares to sign his resignation with Gardner being his witness before Henderson reveals he has retrieved the recording from Heller's men and Jack. Logan then asks Heller to tender his resignation. Later, Logan is told by one of his co-conspirators, [[Graem Bauer|Graem]], that Martha must be silenced. Logan confesses to Martha his culpability in Palmer's death and implores her to remain quiet for the good of the country. Logan tries one final time to control the situation, when Bauer [[Aircraft hijacking|hijacks]] a [[Boeing 727|727]] plane being co-piloted by the man who has the recording. Graem fakes a [[distress signal]] from the plane, giving Logan the [[pretext]] to shoot it down. When the plane makes an [[emergency landing]], Novick talks Logan out of shooting it down. Jack escapes with the tape. Logan and Graem agree that the president must commit suicide, reasoning that his trial would do irreparable damage to the country. After apologizing to Martha, Logan prepares to shoot himself. Before he can, Logan receives a call from [[Miles Papazian]], telling him that he will prevent the [[United States Attorney General|U.S. Attorney General]] from hearing the tape. Once he learns that Papazian has erased the tape, he cancels Bauer's arrest warrant. Logan meets with Aaron Pierce, whom he had taken prisoner before he could meet with Martha several hours earlier. Pierce refuses any deal with Logan, and Logan orders Adams to kill Pierce, although Pierce subsequently escaped with help from Martha and Mike Novick. At 5:59:03 a.m., Martha stalls the president by sleeping with him, allowing Bauer to sneak aboard [[Marine One]]. Once he is aboard, the president is kidnapped and interrogated by Bauer. Jack is unable to extract a confession from Logan, and is arrested by authorities. However, unbeknownst to Logan, Jack secretly placed a [[microtransmitter]] which later records him confessing his deeds to Martha. Logan is consequently arrested by [[United States Marshal|U.S. Marshal]]s during his eulogy of David Palmer, and is led away while Martha and Novick look on. [[Karen Hayes]] speculates that Logan may be granted [[clemency]] for his actions in exchange for his immediate resignation in order to protect the country from the embarrassment of a trial. Hal Gardner was then expected to be sworn in as the new president. It was revealed during Day 6 that Logan resigned from office after pleading guilty to [[obstruction of justice|obstructing justice]], and was placed under [[house arrest]]. His role in Palmer's assassination and the events of Day 5 were not publicized. ===24: Season 6=== When Jack Bauer is left a phone number by his father, [[Phillip Bauer|Phillip]], his call is answered by Logan, who has been placed under [[house arrest]] since Day 5. Logan agrees to help Bauer find [[Dmitri Gredenko]], a Russian national who has supplied Islamic terrorists with [[Soviet Union|Soviet]]-made [[nuclear weapon]]s. Logan reveals that one of Gredenko's supporters, Anatoly Markov, was involved in the conspiracy during Day 5, and that Logan intends to use this knowledge as leverage in order to gain information on Gredenko. He insists that he is looking for [[Salvation#Redemption|redemption]], but Bauer and President Wayne Palmer remain deeply distrustful. Palmer reluctantly grants Logan a temporary release in order to confront Markov. [[Image:Charlesloganday6.jpg|thumb|right|215px|Logan convinces [[Jack Bauer]] to let him talk to Anatoly Markov alone.]] Logan enters a Russian [[consulate]] to confront Markov, threatening to implicate him in the Day 5 conspiracy unless he gives up Gredenko. Markov claims not to know anything. Logan leaves the consulate convinced that Markov is lying, prompting Jack to sneak into the consulate alone to extract information from Markov. When Jack is in their custody, Logan requests he speak to Martha, who is now institutionalized. During the visit, Martha is disgusted by Logan's presence. Just when it is agreed that Martha would make the call, in a sudden fit of rage she stabs him in the shoulder with a kitchen knife, severing an artery. Logan is rushed to the hospital, but begins to flatline en route, with his last words, "Martha" before losing consciousness. He is not heard from for the rest of the season. ===24: Season 8=== Charles Logan makes his first appearance in the season when he offers to help [[Allison Taylor|President Taylor]] with the Russian government, who are attempting to back out of a peace treaty following the assassination of President Omar Hassan.{{cite web|author= |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=fBqf9DzST_c |title=24 8x15/16 Season 8 Episode 15/16 Preview HD |publisher=YouTube |date=2010-04-05 |accessdate=2010-09-27}} The Russians' explanation is they do not believe the new President of the IRK, Hassan's wife Dalia, will be able to hold up the peace agreement; therefore they wish to drop out and have no part in it. Also during this episode it is learned that Logan was granted a presidential pardon from President Daniels. Later, Jack Bauer learns of Logan's involvement in the government cover-up of Russian involvement in the death of President Hassan when he checks the recent calls of the assassin of [[Renee Walker]]. In the following hours, Logan attempts to prevent information about Russian involvement in Hassan's death being released, in order to protect himself and to prevent it undermining the treaty. As in his final hours as President, Logan is willing to go to any lengths to protect himself, including sanctioning murder, torture and press censorship. Logan persuades Taylor to have CTU mole [[Minor government agents in 24#24: Season 8|Dana Walsh]] quietly tortured for the location of the evidence by men hired by him rather than grant her a pardon, and arrest journalist Meredith Reed to prevent her publishing the evidence given to her by Bauer. He also has Taylor place his aide Jason Pillar in charge of the hunt to find Jack Bauer, allowing Pillar to pass on information to Russian agents who will then kill Bauer. Numerous attempts to kill Bauer prove unsuccessful, however, increasing the pressure on Logan. In the meantime Logan's private escort is attacked by Bauer, who kidnaps him and takes him underground. Bauer threatens to kill Logan unless he gives up the names of those behind the day's events: Logan names Novakovich, the Russian foreign minister. Unbeknown to Logan, Bauer also places a microtransmitter on him; Bauer listens in as Logan incriminates himself further in a conversation with Russian President [[Yuri Suvarov]]. Bauer leaves him there unconscious, only fifteen minutes before Novakovich is found dead. Logan is in a hospital bed when the episode ends. Bauer later finds Logan again, intending to use him to lure Suvarov into a trap so Bauer can assassinate him, although he then abandons the plan. When Bauer is eventually captured, Logan makes arrangements for him to be murdered, taking President Taylor's silence as tacit approval. However, at the last moment she refuses to sign the peace treaty and rescinds the order for Bauer's death. Realizing that his plans to kill Jack Bauer and return to political power have failed, Logan murders his right-hand man Jason Pillar and then shoots himself in the head. However, he survives. EMTs responding to the scene believe that he will suffer permanent brain damage. ==Critical reception== {{expand section|date=July 2008}} Gregory Itzin was commended for his portrayal of a weak President, with some critics commenting that the character was partly inspired by [[Richard Nixon]].{{cite web|author=|url=http://tv.zap2it.com/tveditorial/tve_main/1,1002,271%7c100080%7c1%7c,00.html |title=Itzin Is '24's' Petrified POTUS |publisher=Tv.zap2it.com |date=2010-09-23 |accessdate=2010-09-27}} In [[58th Primetime Emmy Awards|2006]], Itzin was nominated for the [[Primetime Emmy Award for Outstanding Supporting Actor in a Drama Series]]. In [[62nd Primetime Emmy Awards|2010]], Itzin was also nominated for the [[Primetime Emmy Award for Outstanding Guest Actor in a Drama Series]] for his appearance in the eighth season for the episode "Day 8: 1:00 p.m. – 2:00 p.m."{{cite web|url=http://www.emmys.com/nominations?tid=86|title=Nominations: Official Primetime Emmy Award Nominees|accessdate=2010-08-08}} ==References== {{Reflist}} {{24 (TV series)}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Logan, Charles}} [[Category:24 (TV series) characters]] [[Category:Fictional American people of English descent]] [[Category:Fictional blackmailers]] [[Category:Fictional business executives]] [[Category:Fictional characters from Santa Barbara, California]] [[Category:Fictional attempted suicides]] [[Category:Fictional characters introduced in 2005]] [[Category:Fictional councillors]] [[Category:Fictional murderers]] [[Category:Fictional Presidents of the United States]] [[Category:Fictional Republicans (United States)]] [[Category:Fictional United States Senators]] [[Category:Fictional Vice Presidents of the United States]]

{{about|the Celtic and Scotland player|the former Clyde F.C. player|Danny McGrain (footballer born 1953)}} {{EngvarB|date=August 2013}} {{Use dmy dates|date=August 2013}} {{Infobox football biography |name = Danny McGrain |image = Danny McGrain (8668845197).jpg |fullname = Daniel Fergus McGrain<ref name="autogenerated428" /> |height = {{height|m=1.78}}<ref>{{cite web|title=Danny McGrain|url=http://www.national-football-teams.com/player/16964/Danny_Mcgrain.html|publisher=National Football Teams|accessdate=6 February 2015}}</ref> |birth_date = {{birth date and age|1950|5|1|df=y}}<ref name="neilb">{{cite web|title=Danny McGrain|url=http://www.neilbrown.newcastlefans.com/player/dannymcgrain.html|publisher=Neil Brown - Post War English & Scottish Football League A - Z Player's Transfer Database|accessdate=6 February 2015}}</ref> |birth_place = [[Finnieston]], Glasgow, Scotland<ref name="neilb" /> |currentclub = [[Celtic F.C.|Celtic]] (Coach) |position = [[Defender (football)|Right back]]<ref name="neilb" /> |youthyears1 = |youthclubs1 = [[Queen's Park F.C.|Queen's Park Strollers]] |youthyears2 = 1967–1970 |youthclubs2 = [[Celtic F.C.|Celtic]] |youthyears3 = |youthclubs3 = [[Maryhill F.C.|Maryhill]]<ref name="neilb" /> |years1 = 1970–1987 |years2 = 1987–1988 |clubs1 = [[Celtic F.C.|Celtic]] |clubs2 = [[Hamilton Academical F.C.|Hamilton Academical]] |caps1 = 439 |caps2 = 21 |goals1 = 4 |goals2 = 0 |totalcaps = 460 | totalgoals = 4 |nationalyears1 = 1973 |nationalteam1 = [[Scottish League XI]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.londonhearts.com/SFL/players/dannymcgrain.html |title=Danny McGrain - Scotland Football League Record from 27 Mar 1973 to 27 Mar 1973 clubs - Celtic |publisher=Londonhearts.com |accessdate=27 August 2013}}</ref> |nationalcaps1 = 1 |nationalgoals1 = 0 |nationalyears2 = 1973 |nationalteam2 = [[Scotland national under-21 football team|Scotland U23]] |nationalcaps2 = 2 |nationalgoals2 = 0 |nationalyears3 = 1973–1982 |nationalteam3 = [[Scotland national football team|Scotland]] |nationalcaps3 = 62 |nationalgoals3 = 0 |manageryears1 = 1992–1994 |managerclubs1 = [[Arbroath F.C.|Arbroath]] |managerclubs2 = }} '''Daniel Fergus McGrain''' {{post-nominals|country=GBR|MBE}} (born 1 May 1950) is a Scottish former professional [[association football|footballer]], who played for [[Celtic F.C.|Celtic]], [[Hamilton Academical F.C.|Hamilton Academical]] and the [[Scotland national football team|Scotland national team]] as a [[Defender (association football)#Full-back|right back]]. McGrain is regarded as one of Scotland's greatest players; sports writer [[Hugh McIlvanney]] commented, "Anybody who saw him at his best had the unmistakable impression of watching a great player, probably one who had no superior anywhere in the world."<ref name="stv">{{cite web |url=http://sport.stv.tv/athletics/163883-danny-mcgrain/?report=comment-16901 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150207010308/http://sport.stv.tv/athletics/163883-danny-mcgrain/?report=comment-16901 |dead-url=yes |archivedate=7 February 2015 |title=Danny McGrain |publisher=STV Sport |date=1 April 2010 |accessdate=27 August 2013 }}</ref>
McGrain began his career at Celtic and was one of the "[[Quality Street Gang (Celtic F.C.)|Quality Street Gang]]", a group of young players that emerged in the late 1960s. He progressed to the first team and went on to play 659 competitive games for Celtic between 1970 and 1987, winning seven [[List of Scottish football champions|League Championships]], five [[Scottish Cup]]s and two [[Scottish League Cup]]s. He spent his final season of his career with [[Hamilton Academical F.C.|Hamilton]], where he helped win them promotion to the [[Scottish Premier Division|Premier Division]]. McGrain played in the [[1974 FIFA World Cup|1974]] and [[1982 FIFA World Cup|1982]] World Cups for Scotland. His 62 caps earned him a place in the [[Scotland national football team roll of honour]] and he was inducted to the [[Scottish Football Hall of Fame]] in 2004.
After retiring from playing, McGrain had a spell as manager of [[Arbroath F.C.|Arbroath]] in the early 1990s, and is now currently part of the coaching staff at Celtic.
==Club career== Born in [[Glasgow]] and raised in the city's [[Drumchapel]] area,<ref name=strong>{{cite web|url=https://www.scotsman.com/sport/football/competitions/premiership/interview-danny-mcgrain-still-going-strong-at-62-1-2782594|title=Interview: Danny McGrain still going strong at 62|author=Aidan Smith|work=[[The Scotsman]]|date=9 February 2013|accessdate=21 July 2018}}</ref><ref name=bhoy>{{cite web|url=http://www.celticfc.net/news/2395?item=2395|title=Becoming A Bhoy: Danny McGrain|author=Mark Henderson|publisher=Celtic F.C.|date=29 March 2012|accessdate=21 July 2018}}</ref> McGrain played for [[Queen's Park F.C.|Queen's Park Strollers]] and also featured for the Scotland Schools team, where he was scouted and signed for [[Celtic F.C.|Celtic]] in May 1967, aged 17.<ref name=bhoy/> He became one of the so-called '[[Quality Street Gang (Celtic F.C.)|Quality Street Gang]]', the great Celtic reserve team that also included players such as [[Kenny Dalglish]], [[Lou Macari]], [[David Hay|Davie Hay]] and [[George Connelly]], who eventually took the places of the ageing [[Lisbon Lions]]. At first, McGrain was regarded as a [[midfielder]] but was utilised in a variety of roles in the [[Reserve team|reserve side]] before becoming established as a [[Defender (association football)#Full-(football)|right-back]].<ref name="gd1">{{cite book|last1=Campbell|first1=Tom|last2=Woods|first2=Pat|title=The Glory & The Dream|year=1987|publisher=Grafton Books|isbn=0-586-20005-3|page=424}}</ref><ref name=bhoy/> He had a spell at [[Scottish Junior Football Association|Junior]] club [[Maryhill F.C.|Maryhill]] to gain experience playing with adults, and also made a fruitless attempt at a college course in engineering prior to becoming a full-time professional.<ref name=bhoy/>
Having been chosen to accompany the main squad to the [[1970 European Cup Final]] along with Dalglish,<ref name=strong/><ref name=bhoy/> McGrain made his first-team debut for Celtic as a substitute in a [[Scottish League Cup]] tie against [[Dundee United F.C.|Dundee United]] at [[Tannadice Park|Tannadice]] on 26 August 1970.<ref name="s7071">{{cite web|url=http://www.fitbastats.com/celtic/player_games.php?playerid=2692&page=17 |title=Celtic Player Danny McGrain, Games Played 1970-71|publisher=Fitbastats.com |date= |accessdate=27 August 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fitbastats.com/celtic/game.php?gameid=10468 |title=Dundee United 2 - 2 Celtic, League Cup (26/08/1970) |publisher=Fitbastats.com |accessdate=27 August 2013}}</ref> He then went on and made his league debut three days later in the opening fixture against [[Greenock Morton F.C.|Morton]] at [[Celtic Park]].<ref name="gd1" /><ref name="s7071" /> McGrain was used sparingly by manager [[Jock Stein]] in his first couple of seasons in the first team, but the young full-back played well in these games.<ref name="gd1" />
Having made only 10 league appearances, McGrain suffered the first serious set-back of his career on 25 March 1972. He sustained a [[Skull fracture|fractured skull]] during a match at [[Brockville Park|Brockville]] against [[Falkirk F.C.|Falkirk]] after a clash of heads with forward [[Doug Somner]].<ref name="gd1" /> McGrain, however, made a full recovery and began the following season, 1972–73, as Celtic's first-choice right-back <ref name="gn">{{cite book|last=Rollin|first=Jack|title=Soccer - Records, Facts & Champions (2nd edition)|year=1988|publisher=Guinness Publishing Ltd|isbn=0-85112-360-0|pages=56–57}}</ref> in place of [[Jim Craig (Scottish footballer)|Jim Craig]] who had left the club at the end of the previous season.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fitbastats.com/celtic/player.php?playerid=2676 |title=Celtic Player Jim Craig Details |publisher=Fitbastats.com |accessdate=27 August 2013}}</ref> McGrain now became a first-team regular and made 30 league appearances that season.<ref name="celt">{{cite web|url=http://www.fitbastats.com/celtic/player.php?playerid=2692 |title=Celtic Player Danny McGrain Details |publisher=Fitbastats.com |accessdate=27 August 2013}}</ref> He also rose through the ranks at international level, making two appearances for the [[Scotland national under-21 football team|Scotland Under 23]] side in the spring of 1973 before finally making his debut at full international level for [[Scotland national football team|Scotland]] in May 1973 against [[Wales national football team|Wales]] at [[Racecourse Ground|Wrexham]].<ref name="gn" /> McGrain picked up his first winner's medal at the end of the season when Celtic clinched their eighth successive league championship title.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Campbell|first1=Tom|last2=Woods|first2=Pat|title=The Glory & The Dream|year=1987|publisher=Grafton Books|isbn=0-586-20005-3|page=271}}</ref>
By the mid 1970s, McGrain was considered by many to be one of the best full-backs in the world.<ref name="gd1" /><ref>{{cite news|title=Your Most Exciting Player 1976-77|url=http://celticunderground.net/wp-content/uploads/2009/01/mcgrain-12.jpg|magazine=[[Shoot (football magazine)|Shoot]]|date=May 1977}}</ref> He played as what is known today as an attacking full-back and contributed significantly in both attacking moves as well as in defence.<ref name="stv" /> His abilities included a burst of speed, skill and control on the ball, vision and anticipation and, when required, a strong but fair sliding [[Tackle (football move)#Association football|tackle]].<ref name="gd2">{{cite book|last1=Campbell|first1=Tom|last2=Woods|first2=Pat|title=The Glory & The Dream|year=1987|publisher=Grafton Books|isbn=0-586-20005-3|page=425}}</ref> He won a further league championship title and a [[Scottish Cup]] in 1974 and played in the [[1974 FIFA World Cup|World Cup]] for Scotland that same year.<ref name="gn" /> However, McGrain was diagnosed with [[Diabetes mellitus|diabetes]] immediately after the World Cup, but with the benefit of medication and a controlled diet and lifestyle, continued to play without adverse effect.<ref name="diab">{{cite web|first=Hugh |last=Keevins |url=http://www.dailyrecord.co.uk/sport/football/celtic-legend-danny-mcgrain-beat-1090383 |title=Celtic legend Danny McGrain: I beat diabetes and so will Scotland kid Scott Allan |newspaper=Daily Record |date=23 December 2011 |accessdate=27 August 2013}}</ref>
In 1977 McGrain won his second league and cup double.<ref>{{cite web|last=Craig |first=Jim |url=http://jimcraigcsc.wordpress.com/2012/05/07/if-you-know-the-history-7th-may-scottish-cup-final-1977/ |title=If You Know The History: 7th May Scottish Cup Final 1977 |publisher=Jimcraigcsc.wordpress.com |date=7 May 2012 |accessdate=27 August 2013}}</ref> He was also voted [[SFWA Footballer of the Year|Player of the Year]] by the [[Scottish Football Writers' Association]].<ref name="poy">{{cite web|url=http://www.rsssf.com/miscellaneous/scotpoy.html |title=Scotland - Player of the Year |publisher=Rsssf.com |date=14 March 2013|accessdate=1 September 2013}}</ref> McGrain became [[Captain (association football)|captain]] of Celtic at the start of season 1977-78 in the wake of [[Kenny Dalglish]]'s departure to [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]]. However, a troublesome foot injury that medical staff struggled to identify or treat adequately saw McGrain miss most of the season with Celtic. He also missed the [[1978 FIFA World Cup|1978 World Cup]] for Scotland.<ref name="gd3">{{cite book|last1=Campbell|first1=Tom|last2=Woods|first2=Pat|title=The Glory & The Dream|year=1987|publisher=Grafton Books|isbn=0-586-20005-3|pages=425–427}}</ref> Celtic finished the season trophy-less and failed to qualify for [[Uefa#Competitions|European competition]] for the first time since the early 1960s.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Campbell|first1=Tom|last2=Woods|first2=Pat|title=The Glory & The Dream|year=1987|publisher=Grafton Books|isbn=0-586-20005-3|page=291}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Hunter|first=William|title=Celtic boys out of their class|page=15|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=Ofw9AAAAIBAJ&sjid=P0kMAAAAIBAJ&pg=5186%2C171284|accessdate=27 August 2013|newspaper=The Glasgow Herald|date=1 May 1978}}</ref> McGrain eventually recovered from his mystery foot injury<ref name="gd3" /> and after a tentative re-introduction into the Celtic team, now managed by [[Billy McNeill]],<ref>{{cite news|last=Reynolds|first=Jim|title=McGrain to face Burnley?|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=QAI-AAAAIBAJ&sjid=cUkMAAAAIBAJ&pg=1664%2C2322821|accessdate=14 May 2015|work=The Glasgow Herald|date=11 September 1978|page=20}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Keevings|first=Hugh|title=Danny's great comeback|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=Zu1AAAAAIBAJ&sjid=aacMAAAAIBAJ&pg=3928%2C3742960|accessdate=14 May 2015|work=Evening Times|date=16 November 1978|page=39}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Davidson|first=Alan|title=Happy Celts: Conn, McGrain on way back|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=Ix4-AAAAIBAJ&sjid=VEoMAAAAIBAJ&pg=5982%2C1021416|accessdate=14 May 2015|work=Evening Times|date=5 March 1979|page=30}}</ref> played in the club's last 18 league fixtures of the season in the spring of 1979.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fitbastats.com/celtic/player_games.php?playerid=2692&page=9 |title=Celtic Player Danny McGrain, Games Played |publisher=Fitbastats.com |accessdate=27 August 2013}}</ref> On his return from injury, a change in his style of play was apparent. There was a noticeable reduction of pace, which in turn was compensated for by a greater reliance on anticipation of play and distribution of the ball.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Campbell|first1=Tom|last2=Woods|first2=Pat|title=The Glory & The Dream|year=1987|publisher=Grafton Books|isbn=0-586-20005-3|page=427}}</ref> McGrain went on to pick up his fourth league championship medal at the end of that season as Celtic clinched the title with a dramatic 4–2 win over [[Rangers F.C.|Rangers]] in their final game of the season.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://image.wikifoundry.com/image/1/8-ttNXWncnZdJW7Fk10qSA474945/GW922H1314 |title=10-man Celtic win the league |newspaper=The Glasgow Herald |date=22 May 1979 |first=Ian |last=Paul |accessdate=27 August 2013}}</ref>
McGrain continued to be a mainstay of the Celtic side during the early to mid 1980s; captaining them to a further three league championships, two Scottish Cups and one Scottish League Cup,<ref name="gn" /> despite also suffering a broken leg in 1981.<ref name=strong/> He made his 600th competitive appearance for Celtic in a 2–0 win over [[St Mirren F.C.|St Mirren]] in October 1985. Manager [[Davie Hay]] described him as a "superb player and professional" and said he was "the best tackler on the field" in the match against St Mirren.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Reynolds|first1=Jim|title=McGrain still going strong after 600 matches for Celtic|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=ucJAAAAAIBAJ&sjid=36UMAAAAIBAJ&pg=2305%2C1629270|newspaper=The Glasgow Herald|accessdate=23 March 2015|page=7|date=7 October 1985}}</ref> In the summer of 1986, [[Airdrieonians F.C. (1878)|Airdrie]] made an approach for McGrain to become their player-manager. Negotiations reached an advanced stage until a last-minute change of heart by the Airdrie board.<ref name="gn" /> McGrain remained at Celtic for a further year; playing regularly at the age of 36: he missed only two games in the second half of the season.<ref name="gn" /><ref name="s8687">{{cite web|url=http://www.fitbastats.com/celtic/player_games.php?playerid=2692 |title=Celtic Player Danny McGrain, Games Played |publisher=Fitbastats.com |accessdate=1 September 2013}}</ref> He played his final game for Celtic on 9 May 1987, a league fixture away against [[Heart of Midlothian F.C.|Hearts]].<ref name="s8687" />
In May 1987, McGrain was given a free transfer by Celtic.<ref name="autogenerated428">{{cite book|last1=Campbell|first1=Tom|last2=Woods|first2=Pat|title=The Glory & The Dream|year=1987|publisher=Grafton Books|isbn=0-586-20005-3|page=428}}</ref> He joined [[Hamilton Academical F.C.|Hamilton Accies]] in the summer and helped them win promotion to the [[Scottish Football League Premier Division|Premier Division]] before finally retiring from playing.<ref name="arb">{{cite web |url=http://www.thecourier.co.uk/sport/football/former-arbroath-fc-boss-danny-mcgrain-backs-lichties-for-the-title-1.41740 |title=Former Arbroath FC boss Danny McGrain backs Lichties for the title |publisher=Thecourier.co.uk |date=20 April 2011 |accessdate=27 August 2013}}</ref>
==International career== His international career began at [[Scotland national under-21 football team|Scotland Under 23]] level on 13 February 1973 with a game against [[England national under-21 football team|England]] at [[Rugby Park|Kilmarnock]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fitbastats.com/scotlandu23/player_games.php?playerid=187 |title=Scotland U23 Player Danny McGrain, Games Played |publisher=Fitbastats.com |accessdate=1 September 2013}}</ref> McGrain played alongside [[Alan Rough]] and [[Asa Hartford]] in a 1–2 defeat.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fitbastats.com/scotlandu23/game.php?gameid=31 |title=Scotland U23 1 - 2 England, Friendly (13/02/1973) |publisher=Fitbastats.com |accessdate=1 September 2013}}</ref> He won a second cap at Under 23 level a month later away to [[Wales national under-21 football team|Wales]], winning 2–1.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fitbastats.com/scotlandu23/game.php?gameid=31 |title=Wales 1 - 2 Scotland U23, Friendly (14/03/1973) |publisher=Fitbastats.com |accessdate=9 February 2015}}</ref>
McGrain made his [[Scotland national football team|full international]] debut for Scotland on 12 May 1973 in a [[British Home Championship]] tie against [[Wales national football team|Wales]] at [[Racecourse Ground|Wrexham]], winning 2–0.<ref name="gn" /><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fitbastats.com/scotland/game.php?gameid=363 |title=Wales 0 - 2 Scotland, British Championship (12/05/1973) |publisher=Fitbastats.com |accessdate=1 September 2013}}</ref> He won a further two caps over the following week in Home Championship ties against [[Northern Ireland national football team|Northern Ireland]] and [[England national football team|England]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fitbastats.com/scotland/player_games.php?playerid=842&page=9 |title=Scotland Player Daniel Fergus McGrain, Games Played |publisher=Fitbastats.com |date= |accessdate=1 September 2013}}</ref> The game against England saw McGrain fielded in an unfamiliar role at left-back to accommodate another highly rated right-back, [[Sandy Jardine]] of Rangers.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fitbastats.com/scotland/game.php?gameid=365 |title=England 1 - 0 Scotland, British Championship (19/05/1973) |publisher=Fitbastats.com |accessdate=1 September 2013}}</ref> McGrain would go on to play at left-back for many of his Scotland appearances in the 1970s in order to accommodate the Rangers player, still able to play to the abilities he displayed in his normal role.<ref name="gd2" />
McGrain played in eight consecutive internationals for Scotland<ref name="gn" /> and was selected by [[Willie Ormond]] for the 22 man squad travelling to [[West Germany]] for the [[1974 FIFA World Cup|1974 World Cup]].<ref name="planetworldcup1974">{{cite web|author=Jan Alsos |url=http://www.planetworldcup.com/CUPS/1974/squad_sco74.html |title=1974 - Squads - Scotland |publisher=Planet World Cup |accessdate=1 September 2013}}</ref> McGrain played in all three World Cup group matches ([[DR Congo national football team|Zaire]], [[Brazil national football team|Brazil]] and [[Yugoslavia national football team|Yugoslavia]]), but despite being undefeated Scotland returned home having failed to qualify for the next phase.<ref name="planetworldcup1974"/> This early-exit from the tournament proved fortunate for McGrain, who had been suffering from extreme thirst all through the tournament and had lost 2 stone (12 kg) in weight. On his return to Glasgow, McGrain was diagnosed as being [[Diabetes mellitus|diabetic]]. Had there been any further delay in identification and treatment of his condition, the consequences could have proved fatal.<ref name="diab74">{{cite web|url=http://www.thefreelibrary.com/Football%3A+Players+are+still+gutted+by+our+KO+in+1974+World+Cup...-a0131005746 |title=Football: Players are still gutted by our KO in 1974 World Cup finals. I'm not - it saved my life; DANNY McGRAIN REVEALS HOW HE BEAT DIABETES TO BECOME SCOTLAND LEGEND |work=Daily Record |date=30 March 2005 |accessdate=1 September 2013}}</ref> With his illness now being managed, McGrain was able to continue playing football.<ref name="diab74" />
McGrain continued to play regularly for Scotland, now being fielded in his more familiar position at right-back, but missed Scotland's ill-fated [[Football World Cup 1978|1978 World Cup]] campaign in Argentina through injury.<ref name="gn" />
On his recovery from injury in 1979, McGrain regained his place in the Scotland team.<ref>{{cite web|last=Paul|first=Ian|title=Stein puts the young ones in driving seat|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=PfM9AAAAIBAJ&sjid=7UgMAAAAIBAJ&pg=3728%2C3662540|work=The Glasgow Herald|accessdate=9 February 2015|date=18 December 1979}}</ref> He made 16 consecutive international appearances in the run up to the [[1982 FIFA World Cup|1982 World Cup]] in Spain. Now [[Captain (association football)|captain]] of the side, McGrain was named in [[Jock Stein]]'s 22 man squad travelling to Spain. He played in Scotland's opening game against [[New Zealand national football team|New Zealand]] but was dropped for the next match against Brazil. McGrain came on as a substitute for [[Gordon Strachan]] in Scotland's third game, against the [[Soviet Union national football team|Soviet Union]].<ref name="gn" /> This transpired to be his final game for Scotland.<ref name="gn" /><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fitbastats.com/scotland/game.php?gameid=452 |title=Scotland 2 - 2 Soviet Union, World Cup (22/06/1982) |publisher=Fitbastats.com |accessdate=1 September 2013}}</ref>
McGrain is a member of the [[Scotland national football team roll of honour]], courtesy of the 62 caps he won during his career.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.scottishfa.co.uk/scottish_football_players.cfm?page=138 |publisher=[[Scottish Football Association]]|accessdate=11 March 2017|title=International Roll of Honour |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110427032517/http://www.scottishfa.co.uk/scottish_football_players.cfm?page=138 |archivedate=27 April 2011}}</ref>
==Coaching career==
After retiring from playing, McGrain had a brief spell coaching at [[Clydebank F.C.|Clydebank]] in 1989.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.heraldscotland.com/sport/spl/aberdeen/mcgrain-drafted-in-to-help-out-bankies-1.615528 |title=McGrain drafted in to help out Bankies |work=Herald Scotland |date=19 August 1989|accessdate=1 September 2013}}</ref>
In November 1992 McGrain was appointed manager of Scottish Second Division side [[Arbroath F.C.|Arbroath]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.heraldscotland.com/sport/spl/aberdeen/mcgrain-takes-over-at-arbroath-1.785397 |title=McGrain takes over at Arbroath |work=Herald Scotland |date=11 November 1992 |accessdate=1 September 2013}}</ref><ref name="arb1">{{cite web |url=http://www.thecourier.co.uk/sport/football/former-arbroath-fc-boss-danny-mcgrain-backs-lichties-for-the-title-1.41740 |title=Former Arbroath FC boss Danny McGrain backs Lichties for the title |publisher=The Courier |date=20 April 2011 |accessdate=1 September 2013}}</ref> That season, McGrain led Arbroath to the quarter-finals of the [[Scottish Cup]], losing 0–3 at home to eventual winners Rangers.<ref name="arb2">{{cite web |url=http://www.arbroathfc.co.uk/history/history_1.htm |title=potted history |publisher=Arbroath FC |accessdate=1 September 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080305023055/http://www.arbroathfc.co.uk/history/history_1.htm |archivedate=5 March 2008 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> The following season Arbroath played McGrain's former club Celtic in a Scottish League Cup tie and lost 1–9, a record defeat for the club.<ref name="arb2" /><ref>{{cite web|first=Ian |last=Paul |url=http://www.heraldscotland.com/sport/spl/aberdeen/paradise-at-the-seaside-as-celtic-hit-the-goal-trail-1.744911 |title=Paradise at the seaside as Celtic hit the goal trail |work=Herald Scotland |date=26 August 1993 |accessdate=1 September 2013}}</ref> McGrain resigned in January 1994 due to illness.<ref name="arb2" /><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.heraldscotland.com/sport/spl/aberdeen/early-inspections-1.723888 |title=Early inspections |work=Herald Scotland |date=18 January 1994 |accessdate=1 September 2013}}</ref> In his 14 months at [[Gayfield Park]], McGrain became popular with their fans and was followed by a group of supporters known as 'Danny McGrain's Bearded Army'. These supporters attended games wearing tribute T-shirts and stick-on beards, affectionately mimicking McGrain's own trademark beard.<ref name="arb1" />
In August 1997 McGrain joined the backroom staff at Celtic, working under [[Wim Jansen]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.heraldscotland.com/sport/spl/aberdeen/paul-goes-to-school-1.385239 |title=Paul goes to school |work=Herald Scotland |date=11 August 1997 |accessdate=1 September 2013}}</ref> After a spell coaching the under-21 side,<ref name="diab74" /> he was made first team coach after being promoted by [[Neil Lennon]] in October 2012 from the [[Celtic F.C. Under-20s and Academy|Development Squad]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www1.skysports.com/football/news/11787/8175219/Celtic-have-appointed-Danny-McGrain-as-new-first-team-coach |title=Celtic have appointed Danny McGrain as new first-team coach |publisher=Sky Sports |date=18 October 2012 |accessdate=1 September 2013}}</ref>
==Personal life== McGrain is married to Laraine, and the couple have three daughters.<ref name=strong/> His younger brother [[Tommy McGrain|Tommy]] was also a footballer who trained with Celtic as a teenager, but he did not break through to the first team and subsequently played for [[Dumbarton F.C.|Dumbarton]].<ref name=drain>{{cite web|url=http://partickthistleahistory.wikifoundry.com/page/1978+Tommy+McGrain+Freed|title=McGrain drain... [scan]|work=[[Evening Times]]|via=Partick Thistle History Archive|date=10 June 1978|accessdate=21 July 2018}}</ref> <ref>{{cite web|url=http://sonsarchive.com/player.php?id=531|title=Tom McGrain - Player Profile|website=Dumbarton Football Club Historical Archive|accessdate=21 July 2018}}</ref>
McGrain supported [[Rangers F.C.|Rangers]] (Celtic's [[Glasgow]] rivals) as a boy. He wrote two autobiographies, one when his career was at its peak and another shortly after he retired. In both, McGrain (a [[Protestant]]) told how he had been spotted by someone doing some scouting for Rangers when he was still a boy but the scout did not recommend him to Rangers, wrongly assuming from his name – Daniel Fergus McGrain – that he was a Catholic and that [[Rangers F.C. signing policy|Rangers would not sign him]] because of this.<ref name="autogenerated428"/> However, McGrain has since stated, "I don't know if that story's true. Over the years that followed nobody from Rangers ever told me they wanted to sign me".<ref>{{cite web|first=Hugh |last=Keevins |url=http://www.dailyrecord.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/danny-mcgrain-neil-lennon-wins-1842862 |title=Danny McGrain: If Neil Lennon wins 10-in-a-row I hope he gets the knighthood that Jock Stein should have got |work=Daily Record |date=20 April 2013 |accessdate=27 August 2013}}</ref><ref name=strong/>
In the summer of 1974, McGrain was diagnosed as suffering from [[diabetes]]. He had just returned home from playing for Scotland in the World Cup in West Germany, where he had displayed an excessive thirst and lost 2 stones (12 kg) in weight. Despite his condition, McGrain was able to continue playing top-level football. In March 2002 McGrain was found by [[Strathclyde Police|Police]] in the south side of Glasgow, slumped unconscious in the driver's seat of his car. He had entered a [[Hypoglycemia|hypoglycaemic]] state, where the brain is drained of sugar and causes the body to shut down to conserve what little there is left. The officers revived McGrain and fed him a sugary sweet. Had McGrain not been found in time he would have suffered brain damage and possibly died. However, he made a full recovery and commented "There was no harm done in the end." <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thefreelibrary.com/DANNY+McGRAIN+IS+FOUND+SLUMPED+AT+WHEEL+OF+HIS+CAR%3B+Scotland+and...-a084124426 |title=Danny McGrain is found slumped at wheel of his car; Scotland and Celtic hero missing for 3 hours after falling unconscious |work=Sunday Mail |date=24 March 2002 |accessdate=1 September 2013}}</ref>
In 2002, [[Celtic F.C. supporters|Celtic supporters]] voted for what they considered to be the greatest Celtic XI of all time. McGrain was voted into the team, which was; [[Ronnie Simpson|Simpson]], McGrain, [[Tommy Gemmell|Gemmell]], [[Bobby Murdoch|Murdoch]], [[Billy McNeill|McNeill]], [[Bertie Auld|Auld]], [[Jimmy Johnstone|Johnstone]], [[Paul McStay|P McStay]], [[Kenny Dalglish|Dalglish]], [[Henrik Larsson|Larsson]] and [[Bobby Lennox|Lennox]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/c/celtic/2245965.stm |title=Jinky best-ever Celtic player |publisher=BBC Sport |date=9 September 2002 |accessdate=1 September 2013}}</ref> He was an inaugural inductee to the [[Scottish Football Hall of Fame]] in 2004,<ref name=sfhof>{{cite web |url=http://www.scottishfootballmuseum.org.uk/scottish_football.cfm?curpageid=1706 |title=Hall of Fame Dinner 2004 |publisher=[[Scottish Football Museum]] |accessdate=21 July 2018 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110315052031/http://www.scottishfootballmuseum.org.uk/scottish_football.cfm?curpageid=1706 |archivedate=15 March 2011 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
McGrain is the Vice Patron of Football Aid, a Scottish charity fund-raising organisation.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.footballaid.com/our-ambassadors/danny-mcgrain-mbe |title=Danny McGrain (MBE) |publisher=Football Aid |date= |accessdate=1 September 2013}}</ref> He has been involved with them since their inception in 2000, and was appointed Vice Patron in 2004.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.footballaid.com/news-match-reports/news/celtic-and-scotland-legend-danny-mcgrain-takes-post-football-aids-first-vice |title=Celtic and Scotland Legend Danny McGrain takes up post of Football Aid's first Vice-Patron |publisher=Football Aid |accessdate=1 September 2013}}</ref>
==In popular culture== In 1996, Glasgow rock band Big Wednesday immortalised Danny in music in their single "Sliding in like McGrain".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thefreelibrary.com/The+latest+from+the+Scots+music+scene.-a061062522 |title=The latest from the Scots music scene |work=The Mirror |date=6 August 1997 |accessdate=1 September 2013}}</ref> Danny appeared on television with the group as part of the promotional activities.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thefreelibrary.com/BITE+BACK%3B+EURO+JUNGLE.-a061254427 |title=Bite Back; Euro jungle |work=Sunday Mail |accessdate=1 September 2013 |date=10 March 1996}}</ref>
